PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Social Security to the closure of the Permanent Building Society in Perth at 5 p.m. last Friday, 30 August, at the direction of the State Government. Is the Minister aware of a media report that social security cheques were diverted from the Permanent Building Society to home addresses of recipients before 5 p.m. on Friday of last week? Can the Minister tell the Senate what prior knowledge the Department of Social Security had and where it came from?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —As far as I know, payments of family allowance and family allowance supplement, which are next due on 5 September, will be made by cheque through the Department's regional offices. We will be attempting to mail the next payment to pensioners by cheque. We will be contacting pensioners so affected to see whether they have made new arrangements. In fact, when I leave the chamber I will be calling the Attorney-General in Western Australia to make arrangements to enable pensioners to get access to the cheques that were paid into the building society last week.
—That is not answering the question.

—It is exactly answering it. The cheques were paid in last week. I am pointing out that we did not have prior knowledge and that the cheques were paid to the building society. As far as I know-I will check this when I leave the chamber-the cheques were paid into the building society in the normal course of events. They have been blocked for release by the administrator. As I understand it, I am to call the Attorney-General in Western Australia when I leave the chamber to try to sort out an arrangement that will enable pensioners to get access to those cheques that were paid to the building society.

ANSWER.PARA: I am not aware of any prior knowledge. In fact, last night I was advised by my Department to contact those responsible in Western Australia to try to make sure that pensioners get access to cheques that were quite normally paid to the building society. In previous instances, such as the Pyramid Building Society last year, my first attempt has always been to try to get pensioners access to their cheques.

Some beneficiaries are affected because some unemployment benefit cheques were also paid in at that late period, and I have to try to get access for those people. I hope to be able to inform the Senate tomorrow of the final arrangements. I do not have a final answer yet. Certainly on the basis of the advice provided to me, there would be no hint of prior knowledge. All our attempts are directed to getting access to the cheques already paid in.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I fully understand what the Minister has said and I fully understand that he is taking action to prevent a recurrence of this situation. I understand that for a while cheques will be directed to the home addresses of the recipients. I want an answer in relation to prior knowledge. There was a report in the media at 6 p.m. last Friday that there was prior knowledge and that some cheques had already been diverted. If the Minister is not aware whether there was prior knowledge, will he seek to find out? If there was prior knowledge, I believe that everyone should have had the same prior knowledge.

—I thought that I had pointed out that, on the basis of the information supplied to me, there could have been no prior knowledge. All we are talking about is preventing the next payment going into the Society but going directly to pensioners and taking steps to enable pensioners to gain access to the last payment which was paid in. On the basis of the information supplied to me, there is no hint of prior notice, so all I can do is deny that. But, as I said, I will check with the Department to see whether there is anything that I have not been told.

Is the Minister aware of a media release issued by the so-called tax reform campaign group, for which Senator Michael Baume is the contact, which makes the statement that the Australian Taxation Office in New South Wales collected more than $24.8 billion in wholesale sales tax in the financial year 1989-90? Can the Minister advise the Senate how much sales tax was collected nationally in 1989-90 and how this compares with the amazing figure in the Liberal's media release?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —That unfortunate matter has been drawn to my attention. There was a media release issued by the so-called tax reform campaign group, for which Senator Michael Baume was named as the contact. It is very interesting that Senator Baume is very much into third party endorsements of his own activities. I recall him as chairman of the Waste Watch Committee--
—And a good one.

—He was a good one. The only waist he did not watch was his own during that period; he just got bigger and bigger as that function went on. Senator Baume is into it again, just as he was in the 1987 election, putting out totally incorrect figures. After all, the Opposition has been trying to make something of the fact that sales tax collections in 1989-90--
—We are trying to keep you on the front foot today from the start.
—The Opposition has been trying to make something of the fact that sales tax collections in 1989-90, nationally, were in the order of $10 billion. Senator Lewis might be interested in this.
—No, he has retired.

—I know that Senator Lewis has retired to the back bench. We all know why he retired: it was something to do with figures. It is extraordinary that this tax reform campaign group should put out these sorts of figures. The Opposition has said nothing about the fact that when this Government came to office sales tax receipts amounted to 11 per cent of total revenue. For the 1991-92 income tax year, the Budget estimates are that sales tax receipts will be 9.5 per cent of total revenue.

ANSWER.PARA: This is totally contrary to the point which this bodgie press release, succoured by the Opposition, sought to make. This press release cited $24.8 billion worth of sales tax receipts. I understand that the Taxation Office was so upset by the contents of this press release that it departed from normal procedure and contacted the office of the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, to point out to him that the Opposition was putting out totally incorrect figures about sales tax.

The figure that the Opposition used was, in fact, the total indirect income rather than the tax. I understand that later in the day the Opposition tried to issue a corrected front page statement with the correct figure for New South Wales sales tax receipts being $4.5 billion. I am not aware of what steps the Opposition took to advise those newspapers which reported the incorrect figure but I assume that something was done about it.

I just want to make the point that this Opposition has been in opposition for a long time. Every time it has got near the barrier it has tripped over because of bodgie figures-rubbery figures-on tax deductions, Medicare and everything. Prior to an election the Opposition has tripped over on rubbery figures or inadequate leadership. Those are the issues on which it has tripped over. I am just trying to help the Opposition by uttering a warning that if it goes on with this bodgie figure stuff, it is going to trip over again.

The Opposition has tripped over with this issue because it has relied on the genius of Senator Michael Baume to endorse this statement by the so-called tax reform group. There is a lesson in this for all honourable senators opposite. I think the people of Australia are very concerned that there should be an improvement in parliamentary performance. They expect a little better performance from the Opposition than lying publicly in documents about figures in respect of sales tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell me about Michelle Grattan's calculator.

—Senator Parer, by way of interjection, indicates that he knew what the correct figures were. This answer has not been addressed to him at all because he seems to be quite well-informed and honourable about this issue. The rest of the senators opposite yell their heads off all the time because they do not want to face up to the fact that they are again disseminating misinformation and lies about the fundamental question of the level of sales tax in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. I ask: is the Minister aware that the Tasman Institute has recently released a report entitled Global Warming-its Economics and Politics? Has the Minister any comments on the report which questions the science of the greenhouse climate change and claims that adherence to the Toronto target on greenhouse gas emission reductions would cost Australia more than 16 per cent of its current GDP and lead to the loss of $50 billion from the coal industry?
—Have you read it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not had access to the full report but I know that the Minister, Mrs Kelly, and her Department have had some opportunity to examine the report. In any event, it would not need close examination to be able to refute and rebut some of its claims. The claims that are made by the Tasman Institute on the science of greenhouse I would have thought are quite easy to rebut. In fact, if one looks at the reports by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change it will be seen that that group was established by the World Meteorological Organisation and the United Nations Environment Program and that it comprised the largest group of scientists ever to have worked on the global warming issue. It involved 170 scientists from 25 countries, with an additional 200 scientists involved in peer review. At the Second World Climate Conference held in Geneva last year, 700 scientists from over 100 countries supported the findings of the group's report. It was stated in that report:

ANSWER.PARA: We are certain of the following:
There is a natural greenhouse effect which already keeps the earth warmer than it would otherwise be.

Emissions resulting from human activities are substantially increasing the atmospheric concentrations of the greenhouse gases . . . these increases will enhance the greenhouse effect, resulting on average in an additional warming of the earth's surface.

One wonders how more concrete one would have to be, or how more scientific an analysis would have to be, before a statement of that kind could be made. It is clear that the Tasman Institute just does not have the scientific expertise to refute the findings of a report compiled by the hundreds of scientists from around the world who have looked at this one.

One has seriously to question the Tasman Institute when it comes to the question of costs. It should be pointed out that many studies have been carried out in Australia on the costs and benefits of reducing greenhouse gas emissions. Some of those studies done by industry and energy sectors do acknowledge that considerable reductions in greenhouse gas emissions can be made without net costs and, in some cases, with net benefits by improving the efficiency in the way in which we use energy. Unfortunately, the Tasman Institute ignores those options completely. In the Tasman Institute report it is assumed that the Government would adopt an horrendous tax on energy to suppress demand. Of course, that is fallacious in the first place. It is well beyond any reasonable basis of experience in energy pricing.

Honourable senators will recall that the interim planning target for reducing greenhouse gas emissions adopted by the Government has a very important qualifier placed on it. That qualifier is that Australia will not proceed with measures which have net adverse economic impacts nationally or on Australia's trade competitiveness in the absence of similar action by major greenhouse gas producing countries.
The Industry Commission is currently conducting an inquiry into the question of the costs and benefits of reducing greenhouse gas emissions. Its draft report released on 22 August stated:

The costs and benefits of an international consensus to reduce greenhouse gas emissions depend on many complex scientific, economic, political and strategic considerations . . . . The Commission considers that this question is unanswerable at the present time.

The Industry Commission has had access to many studies and submissions, including the one from the Tasman Institute. It is clear from the methodology and conclusions regarding costs that the Tasman Institute has not passed the Industry Commission test and will not pass any credible scientific test in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade aware of the call by the Centre for Defence Information in Washington, DC, for an emergency session of the United Nations Security Council on the question of stability of Soviet nuclear weapons, and does the Government support that call? Secondly, does the Minister agree that the breakdown of the Soviet Union and the creation of new independent nations represent one of the most significant nuclear proliferation problems of the nuclear age? Finally, will the Government ensure that the United Nations has full access to information gathered at Pine Gap and Nurrungar on the state of the Soviet command and control system for nuclear weapons?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the first question, I have become aware of the statement of the Centre for Defence Information in Washington as a result of Senator Powell's question, but not otherwise. Certainly the question of potential proliferation of nuclear weapons to new states is a very real one in the context of current developments in the Soviet Union. I am sure that is an issue of which the Security Council members will already be very conscious. In the event that they should decide it to be appropriate for the Security Council to formally consider the matter, then Australia will support that.

ANSWER.PARA: As far as the situation with nuclear warheads in the Soviet Union is concerned, the details of the information available to me in this respect are as follows: all told, the number of nuclear warheads deployed in the USSR at the moment is in the vicinity of 27,000. The majority of the strategic warheads-about three quarters of them-are located in the Russian republic, the remainder being located in three other republics, which are Byelorussia, the Ukraine and Kazakhstan. In addition to those strategic warheads, a very large number of tactical nuclear weapons are deployed with warheads in most of the union republics. The strategic ones are in about four republics and the tactical ones are in most of the rest. All told, something over 27,000 warheads are currently deployed. The emergence in the Soviet Union of a new structure of uncertain dimensions at this stage and with uncertain authority as far as military matters are concerned does raise questions as to where the command and control for these warheads will be located.

It is our understanding at the moment that the central Soviet Union military authorities are presently maintaining very tight control of all of the country's nuclear weapons. Moreover, it is the case that most republics, including the Ukraine and Kazakhstan, have already declared publicly that they have no intention of becoming nuclear weapons states. There is the further very welcome development of the decree issued a few days ago by the President of Kazakhstan ending nuclear tests at Semipalatinsk, the Soviet Union's biggest nuclear test site.

Certainly, we would expect the leaders of the USSR and the various republics to cooperate fully in maintaining a firm, undisputed and responsible control over all nuclear weapons. We would certainly welcome an early announcement by newly independent republics of their intention to be non-nuclear weapon states parties to the Treaty on the Nonproliferation of Nuclear Weapons, thereby submitting all peaceful nuclear facilities on their territory to IAEA safeguards.

Whether the end result of the process which is currently at work in the Soviet Union will mean, in fact, that more than the Baltic states will be fully independent sovereign republics of course remains to be seen; so one cannot take completely at face value the declarations of independence that have so far been made. But, to the extent that those declarations are followed through with the achievement of genuinely sovereign independent statehood by the republics in question, it will be a very real question about their involvement in the NPT, and the point I have just made will hold.

As to the last part of the question, about information from Pine Gap and Nurrungar on the state of the Soviet command and control system, it is a wholly hypothetical question as to whether the Security Council would want access to any such information. In the event that such information is sought in the future, we will, of course, give consideration to supplying it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Can the Government confirm that it has instituted an inquiry into the obstacles that exist to the adoption of national standards in occupational health and safety? Can the Minister advise honourable senators whether this inquiry has been completed, what its findings are and whether the Government is in a position to respond to those findings?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, the Government did institute an inquiry into the non-uniformity of national standards in occupational health and safety in Australia. I have said in this chamber before that next year there will be common standards in occupational health and safety right across the countries of Europe. In Australia, we have not managed to succeed in obtaining uniformity of standards between the States and the Commonwealth. There is concern in Australian industry about the cost that is imposed in meeting disparate standards if an industry operates in more than one State. It was partly because of that and partly because of other concerns raised by industry that I commissioned an inquiry into the matter by Dr Peter Grabosky of the Australian Institute of Criminology. As far as I know, Dr Grabosky is no relation to Count Grabosky of the Steve Vizard show-in case anyone is interested.
—No, we are not.

—No-one is interested. Dr Grabosky has now reported and he has identified the following major impediments: the complexity of the standards development process involving tripartite consultation in nine separate jurisdictions; resistance to change in general and a desire by the jurisdictions to control their own agendas; and the array of drafting conventions which are incompatible across States. The report described the duplication of effort in nine separate jurisdictions as `wasteful and inefficient' and `an unnecessary burden on Australian taxpayers'. Dr Grabosky concludes that the achievement of uniformity is largely a matter of political will between the States with the support of the Commonwealth.

ANSWER.PARA: His major recommendations are as follows: a systematic rationalised process of standards development, the implementation of which should be developed cooperatively, with Worksafe Australia playing a central role in coordination; the formation of a national information network coordinated by Worksafe publicising the contributions of States and Territories through conferences, seminars, et cetera; and the production of a marketing strategy for the adoption of national standards. He recommends a range of options to overcome impediments in legislative drafting.
Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I conclude my answer by noting the persistent interjections from the Opposition. It is pretty typical: the Opposition has not been interested at any time in trying to improve occupational health and safety in this country.

Secondly, given that the Government has claimed that all expending initiatives have been funded by spending cuts or revenue increases, how would this revenue loss be funded? —Well, what does it mean?

Senator Bishop asked whether, in the course of considering the fiscal position adopted by the Government in the Budget, there will be, as she puts it, `some change to the ridiculous better cities program'. I, of course, cannot say anything about that except that I am not persuaded that it is ridiculous by anything that Senator Bishop has said. Senator Bishop also referred to loose fiscal policy. She started to say `monetary policy', and then--
—No, I asked what the cost of this lax policy was.

—Senator Bishop said `fiscal policy'.
—Lax policy.
—This is Senator Bishop's third go, is it? It is now tax policy.

—If Senator Bishop wants me to hear her, she should do something about her delinquent colleagues who make noises all the time when she is trying to ask questions. I do not think that they treat Senator Bishop's questions with sufficient respect. They shout and yell when she asks questions and I cannot always hear them.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Bishop referred to lax fiscal policy, as I understand it. The fiscal policy adopted by this Government has not been lax. It has been widely recognised as not being lax throughout the history of the Government. Of course, only in the context of this Budget have the hard men on the Opposition side-Dr Hewson and Senator Jim Short-suggested that fiscal policy has been lax. Dr Hewson and Senator Short have suggested that there should be no Budget deficit, that there should be $4.7 billion removed from the Budget deficit, and that the Budget should be in balance. That is all very well if one is in Opposition and government is Sunday Too Far Away stuff. It is all right if one is in that position. The fact of the matter is that if $4.7 billion had not been there as a structural deficit in the Budget we would have had literally thousands and thousands more people unemployed.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is absolute nonsense.

—No, it is not absolute nonsense. It comes back to the central problem of the Opposition: it does not know whether it is tough or soft; it does not know whether it is tough or compassionate. Senator Baume comes in here as the bleeding heart--

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I know that Senator Button enjoys a little meander around a subject matter or two, but when he elects to answer a question he is required to so answer and not to go off on a frolic of his own. If he does not want to answer, he should just sit down. I ask you to rule that way.
—Order! There is no point of order. It is becoming a very long answer, Senator Button.
—I have already answered the question, but I thought it would be helpful to Senator Bishop to see it in its proper context so that next time we might get a better question.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I can hardly say `Thank you for the answer, Minister', because it was not an answer. In light of the letter I received from the Minister yesterday, when we were dealing with figures, and his assertion that the figures he had given before were correct, when he had to say `I stand corrected', perhaps he could stand corrected here this morning as well. If it is a fact that the Minister is saying that the $3.50 is not to be dropped, does that mean that the Government will be increasing the levy payment?
—I have already answered the question. I could perhaps say something, but I have already answered it.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories aware of concern in the Murray Valley about the possible environmental consequences of the de-inking plant to be developed at Albury? What will those consequences be and what are the environmental advantages that should follow its establishment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The issue of recycling in Australia has been growing in recent years, and I would have thought the announcement of a de-inking plant in Albury would be welcomed by most Australians. It certainly is the best of news for paper recycling, especially for the recycling of newsprint. One of the great difficulties has been that, as people dutifully put out newspapers for recycling, all that the companies have been able to do is to store them. Even storage space for those newspapers has been running very short over the past two years.

ANSWER.PARA: Obviously, some people downstream from Albury quite reasonably are concerned about the additional salt load this may create in the end. However, the Managing Director of Australian Newsprint Mills has given the Government an assurance that the recycling mill will not result in an increase in the amount of salt discharged into the Murray River. In fact, the company will be taking steps to ensure that it assists the Government in reducing salt levels downstream. Waste water that is presently discharged does meet World Health Organisation standards for drinking water, and it will continue to be subject to primary, secondary and tertiary treatment to keep it that way.

If we are to continue having any really good news for the environment, obviously steps along the recycling path will be integral in any national strategy of waste minimisation. They should reduce the increasing pressure on Australia's forests by replacing virgin pulp from our native forests with recycled pulp from old newspapers, all without increasing pollution of the Murray River. There is no point in recycling any product that does not have a market, and this plant has a guaranteed market for its product. That will ensure its viability and the viability of the whole recycling system. It will help meet our target of a 50 per cent reduction in waste going to landfill by the year 2000.

ANM is also looking closely at minimising water use and at reusing water for irrigation of public parks and pine plantations. The company has announced that ultimately it intends to phase out river discharge completely for the nine non-winter months of the year.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. It refers the Minister to the Prime Minister's parliamentary statement that there were no plans to terminate the controlled timber logging industry on Fraser Island which, in his words, provided 180 jobs in saw mills and a further 300 jobs indirectly. The Prime Minister said these valuable and desperately needed jobs would continue and that they would not be abandoned. The Minister also gave an assurance when he was Minister for the environment that World Heritage listing of Fraser Island was not under consideration by the Commonwealth Government and there were no plans to terminate the present timber logging industry. In light of these two senior-level assurances, how can the Government justify taking away these 480 unionist jobs? Is this another example of the Government's sell-out of the workers to cement the green vote?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Boswell may recall that during my term as environment Minister we did have a couple of arguments with the States about environmental matters. I am certain that Senator Boswell will recall that one of the States the Commonwealth had some arguments with was the State of Queensland when the National Party of Australia ruled it. Given the arguments over World Heritage listings in north Queensland and in Tasmania-and he will recall that they were very significant arguments-the Commonwealth determined that it would have to be only under the most extreme circumstances that World Heritage listings would be pursued without the agreement of the States. Given that there was absolutely no possibility of the State of Queensland agreeing to anything in respect of Fraser Island, it was certainly not on any priority list of mine nor of the Prime Minister during that time.

ANSWER.PARA: Equally, I am sure the honourable senator will recall that the Bjelke-Petersen era passed and that eventually Mr Cooper, as Premier, was defeated by Wayne Goss. I think that was a great day for all Queenslanders. When that occurred, the honourable senator will also recall, Premier Goss appointed someone called Tony Fitzgerald to investigate the possibilities of World Heritage listing of Fraser Island. I am sure the honourable senator will remember who he was. Just as he had conducted a magnificent investigation into Queensland corruption, so he conducted a magnificent investigation into World Heritage values on Fraser Island.

The conclusions Mr Fitzgerald came to led Premier Goss, Mrs Kelly and the Prime Minister to come to an agreement on World Heritage listing for, I think, the Great Sandy Region, not just Fraser Island. Another memorable, forward-thinking and excellent decision was taken by this Government on the environment and it simply represents a continuation of the policies that we have had in the past and that I am certain will continue in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I have listened to the Minister's answer carefully and what I have deducted is that the Prime Minister's word and his word have absolutely no credibility at all; once they have given an assurance it can be withdrawn at any time. Am I making a correct assumption?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought I had made it perfectly clear that the attitude that the Prime Minister had taken, and that I had taken, was that the agreement of the State of Queensland would--
—That is not what you said.
—It certainly was what I said.
—Not back in those days.

—It was. It is exactly what I said at the time. I said it repeatedly in this place. Senator Macdonald is new here; he would not know. But Senator Boswell would know, and I made it very plain in this place time and time again that the agreement of States would be almost a prerequisite. As I said, only in the most extreme circumstances would we proceed without it. When it came to the Great Sandy Region, the facts were that Mr Fitzgerald conducted an investigation in an inquiry set up by Premier Goss. The conclusions from that investigation were that the area was worthy of World Heritage recognition. The Commonwealth has negotiated with the Goss Government to concur with that decision, and I stand by it.

ANSWER.PARA: It in no way reflects upon the word of either the Prime Minister or myself. It does reflect upon the fact that Mr Fitzgerald first found that the government which had previously been there was crook. It was also found that its attitude to Fraser Island was wrong. On the basis of Mr Fitzgerald's report, we have proceeded.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Australian Industrial Relations Commission: Workplace Bargaining

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Can the Minister advise the Senate whether the Government has lodged its written submission to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission's review of the wage fixing principles? Can the Minister say whether or not the Government's submission supports a move to workplace bargaining within flexible guidelines supported by the IRC? How does the submission aim to advance the Government's strategy on workplace reform?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Monday the Government lodged a written submission to the Industrial Relations Commission as the basis for the review of the national wage fixing guidelines that the Commission brought down in its national wage case decision in April this year. The review of the national wage case guidelines has been brought on earlier than anticipated at the time of the national wage case decision by a decision of the Commission arising out of the waterfront application made some months back.

ANSWER.PARA: I must say that I welcome the decision of the Commission to review, at an earlier time, the guidelines for decentralising the centralised wage fixing system with a greater focus on the workplace. I would certainly welcome a decision from the Commission out of this review which would adopt the Government's submission and prescribe guidelines for workplace bargaining.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a bit surprising.
—Well, it is a very important submission.
—Adopting the Government's position.

—The purpose of putting a submission is to try to persuade it adopt one's position, and that is what I would like. The next wage system would be enhanced considerably if, as I have said, a decentralised system allowed for greater scope for negotiations between unions and management so that they can accept a greater responsibility for the outcome of those negotiations. The packages negotiated should be processed with and through the Industrial Relations Commission. The Commission should have regard to maximum flexibility in the form in which the wage packages are negotiated, with productivity bargaining being, I would think, a key feature of it.

ANSWER.PARA: We argue that the guidelines that we have submitted to the Commission are the ones that it should adopt through workplace bargaining; that increases should be linked to demonstrable gains in productivity and flexibility; that negotiations must not be based on workplace arrangements reached elsewhere-they must be specific to the particular workplace, although it should be said that it is possible in industry sectors to negotiate a framework agreement within which the companies in an industry sector would negotiate specific agreements, and that has occurred in the metals industry; that any agreement should be fair to all relevant employees; and that the minimum basis of workplace bargaining must be national award standard conditions of employment, including leave standards, standard hours and redundancy provisions.

The Government does support comprehensive fixed term agreements and a no extra claims agreement would apply during the life of those fixed term agreements. We, in our submission, indicated support for the metal trades negotiated outcome, recognising that that is an appropriate settlement for that sector of the economy. We have called upon the Industrial Relations Commission to evolve from its detailed and prescriptive measures and to facilitate the shift to decentralised wage fixing.

We support a further review by the Commission late this year or early next year in which the question of a general increase in wages can be considered. We raise that because what we have asked the Commission to do this time is prescribe guidelines for workplace bargaining. But we recognise that not every worker in this country is in a position to negotiate for greater productivity. Indeed, there is the question of whether employers would want to negotiate a wage round specific to a company. From an equity point of view and in the interests of protecting low income earners in this country, it may be necessary late this year or next year to revisit the question of wages from the point of view of whether or not a general wage increase should apply.

—Can the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs comment on measures announced by the New South Wales Premier, Mr Greiner, to ban the sale and resale of certain categories of rifles and shotguns? Does the Minister believe that this will assist moves to a nationwide approach to the control of guns in the Australian community?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the announcement by Mr Greiner, the Premier of New South Wales, of measures that he has foreshadowed to ban the sale of high powered semi-automatic rifles and shotguns. I believe it is a very constructive first step, a token of good faith in relation to the necessity to rid the Australian community of these sorts of weapons, and I certainly do welcome it. It coincides with the steps taken already by the Federal Government to ban the import of military style semi-automatics into this country, particularly those produced by the Soviet and Red Chinese armies which were flooding into this country in the latter part of last year.

ANSWER.PARA: I believe that this is a good step in New South Wales. It follows a very dramatic step taken several days ago by Terry Connolly, the police Minister here in the ACT, who announced very stringent measures in this regard. It coincided with an announcement by Michael Weldon, the Tasmanian police Minister, of the decision by the Tasmanian Government to ban the sale of military style semi-automatics in Tasmania and to introduce a stringent licensing system in relation to other sorts of firearms. Senator Jones, as a senator from Queensland, will be interested to know that only today Mr Terry Mackenroth, the police Minister in Queensland, has said that he will move to ban semi-automatic weapons in Queensland later this year.

So we have a situation where nationwide there has been a complete change in philosophy, shared by both conservative and Labor governments in State, Territory and Federal administrations. The argument that people kill other people, not guns kill people, has been rejected in favour of the proposition that not only must we have a stringent licensing system for those who have access to weapons but also we must reduce the arsenal of particularly lethal weapons available in the community. That change of philosophy is a very important underpinning of this nationwide approach which is emerging.

To those who say that we should not ban these sorts of weapons but should have a more stringent licensing system, it is important to point out to them that about 80 in every 100 of the killings achieved by use of a weapon are carried out by those with no previous criminal or psychiatric history. That means, of course, that it is very hard to weed out those who may reach for a weapon at the moment they cross the threshold of violence, either breaking under some particular stress or in a domestic violence situation. We have to ensure that when they reach for a weapon it is not of that particularly lethal kind that, as I say, has been flooding into the country-the semi-automatics. The step taken by Premier Greiner is to be welcomed and it now means that we have a very good foundation for going to the police Ministers conference in October in order to produce resolutions to go to the Premiers Conference.

The Premiers Conference will be very important in that it will put the question of gun laws in the wider context of dealing with violence in our community. The National Committee on Violence set up after the Hoddle Street and Queen Street massacres has already provided a tremendous range of recommendations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Look at some of the videos, too.

—I agree. These recommendations deal with the whole cultural underpinning of violence in our society. I believe that, with that wider approach to the question of violence, the question of gun laws can be seen in context. They will be a very important part of the nationwide approach that now appears to be emerging.

PETITION.TITLE: Tobacco Advertising
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we the undersigned call for urgent action by our Federal Parliament and all government agencies concerned with Health and Sport to impose an immediate ban on the incidental advertising of tobacco products on television and provide for alternative funding to replace tobacco sponsorship. That tobacco sponsorship of sporting events and participants openly flouts the 1976 Federal law prohibiting tobacco advertising on TV and radio. That our Parliament immediately end this association between healthy sports and the deaths of 18,300 people in Australia each year from tobacco-related diseases.
And your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Bjelke-Petersen (from 21 citizens), Senator Brownhill (from 127 citizens) and Senator Chapman (from 25 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Smokefree International Flights

(i) are alarmed at the health and safety hazards that arise from the smoking of cigarettes and other tobacco products on international airlines, a dangerous practice banned within Australia;

(ii) call for the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) of which Australia is a member to set a standard for smokefree international flights; standards set by ICAO must be agreed to by its 162 member nations.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Bell (from 59 citizens) and Senator Devereux (from 120 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Aidex 1991
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That attention is drawn to Australia's location and involvement in the Asia/Pacific region where there exists a number of actual and potential conflicts, along with several countries which can ill afford to pay for the importation of military equipment yet feel obliged to do so.

That Australia is increasing its role in the arms trade in this region, and in particular, it is supporting and participating in AIDEX `91. The arms trade is detrimental to Australians affected by the diversion of public money away from health, education, social welfare, and is an integral factor in the oppression and poverty of people of the Asia/Pacific region.
The petitioners therefore appeal to the Australian Parliament to:
Stop all military aid and training to governments engaged in repression of their own people.

Direct those Government Departments participating in AIDEX `91, i.e. Defence, Austrade, Industry, Technology and Commerce, to cancel their bookings for space at the exhibition and withdraw their support for AIDEX `91.
Redirect all monies currently being used in promoting the arms industry to socially useful research, development and production.
Explore the possibilities of setting up an Agency for the development of techniques for conflict resolution.
Increase overseas aid to counteract the reduction since 1983/4.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom: 0055 Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
(1) Telecom is selling 0055 telephone networks to private contractors who provide offensive and sexually explicit recorded messages to the public.

And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

The petition of the undersigned shows the very deep concern of people in the community against the proposed AIDEX exhibition of weapons of war in our country. We firmly believe that it is not in Australia's interest to become dealers in death and destruction. Particularly at this time when our planet's environment is in a parlous condition and demands statesmanlike leadership to the world on its rehabilitation. We therefore ask that:

The Exhibition to take place be one which shows instead the ways in which we aim to overcome the dangers to our world from poisoned soil, air and water by high-lighting the need for tree-planting, solar-powered homes, electric cars, etc. as a means of attacking the global warming and other hazards to our fragile environment.
And we, your humble petitioners will as in duty bound, ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom: 0055 Services

The readily available range of sex and fantasy audio text services transmitted via Telecom through the use of the 0055 prefix.
We request the Senate to move to disband this ``adult'' information and entertainment service because of the affect these messages have on our youth and Australia's moral standing.
And your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Disability Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The Petition of the undersigned shows that people with disabilities in South Australia are extremely concerned about changes to the Social Security Act contained in the above Bill which would:
severely reduce the benefit available to people with disabilities under 21 years of age, despite the fact that the unavoidable extra costs of their disabilities have not been reduced;

make it more difficult for people with disabilities which come and go or those which are not clearly measurable (such as mental disorders or other hidden disabilities) to gain and keep secure means of support;
introduce punishments, not incentives, for people with disabilities to seek training and work;
create gross overload on a rehabilitation and training system which even now is unable to properly meet the needs of people with disabilities, with no promise of substantial extra resources;
stop non-medical factors such as local labour market conditions, difficulty with English and others being considered in deciding eligibility for a Disability Support Pension.

Your petitioners ask that the Senate not pass this legislation until all problems raised with it by people with disabilities and their representatives have been resolved and in any case not before January 1, 1992.

PETITION.TITLE: Regular Defence Force
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we believe our Government's first duty to its citizens is to provide them with the full protection of an upgraded regular defence force.
That it should not cut back as has been proposed.
That as taxpayers, we feel we have the right to have fully operational regular defence forces to ensure peace for our nation.

The speech read as follows-

This Bill is a machinery financing measure to enable certain defence expenditures to be met from the Loan Fund rather than from the Consolidated Revenue Fund and to supplement the moneys available to the Consolidated Revenue Fund. Successive Governments have adopted the practice of introducing a Loan Bill to authorise the issue of moneys from the Loan Fund to meet expenditures that have been appropriated by the Parliament, but for which insufficient funds are available in the Consolidated Revenue Fund.
Legally, expenditure from the Consolidated Revenue Fund cannot exceed the moneys available to that Fund.

The purpose of this Bill is to make provision for the financing of the prospective 1991-92 Budget deficit. The Budget deficit in prospect for 1991-92 gives rise to a deficit in the Consolidated Revenue Fund some $5.5 billion greater. This situation arises because appropriations from the Fund include various items that are classified as financing transactions rather than Budget outlays, and thus do not affect the Budget outcome. These items include payments to the National Debt Sinking Fund and superannuation payments made by the Commonwealth on behalf of public trading enterprises.

The Bill provides authority for the loan fund to meet defence expenditures incurred after the passage of the Bill that otherwise would have been met from the Consolidated Revenue Fund, and to supplement the Consolidated Revenue Fund so that it can meet its other commitments. The Bill also provides the borrowing authority to cover these payments from the Loan Fund. The Bill does not authorise expenditures additional to those already appropriated, or currently before the Parliament, apart from loan raising expenses, which will be small.

I emphasise that the Bill does not in any way impinge upon the prerogative of the Parliament to appropriate public moneys, but simply provides the means to finance expenditures previously approved and appropriated by the Parliament.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and I present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 3 September, on motion by Senator Collins:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —When we adjourned last night I was reading from the Social Security Review Issues Paper No. 5, Enabling Policies for People with Disabilities, commonly known as the Cass report. I was almost through the quote so I will finish it now:

SPEECH.PARA: In other words, full account would be taken of the possible compounding effects of socio-economic and labour market circumstances on the level and nature of impairment and the consequent effects on employment capacity.

We are saying that the Bill which is before us is vastly different from this report. The Social Security (Disability and Sickness Support) Amendment Bill 1991 has not taken up the vast majority of recommendations and, in particular, the most important recommendations from this report. I have read this rather long passage to demonstrate just how far away the Government is from the findings of this review. I must add that the review was funded by the taxpayers and it seems that it is one that has been gathering dust on a shelf somewhere.

The Australian Democrats believe very strongly that functional impairment alone is not a full test of a person's capacity to work and that other factors must be taken into account when determining a person's eligibility for income support. We are not trying to remove the screening process from this Bill, and we are not saying that recipients of support pensions should not be encouraged to undertake vocational and educational programs or that work force transition should not be a goal. However, we are saying that it is wrong, both medically and socially, simply to equate a person's impairment with his or her ability to work and fail to take other factors into account.

This approach was brought up over and over again as the Committee met and heard from witnesses. In particular, I want to read from the submission of the Philomata Legal Service to the Senate Committee. The submission states:

Impairment is a term used to describe limits in function compared to what is considered normal in human beings. Impairment can be physical, intellectual, psychiatric or sensory. Incapacity is a loss or limitation of opportunity to take part in the life of the community on an equal level with others due to physical of functional barriers. While impairment can be treated as a medical concept, incapacity is a function of the' relationship between impairment and a wide range of social and economic factors.

The Cass report understood this distinction but the Government either does not understand it or is being deliberately obtuse in order to cut costs. Again I ask: was this Bill really designed by economists? As the Cass report noted there are two types of non-medical factors: the first relates to a person's socio-economic resources, such as age, educational qualifications and skills; the second relates to the reasonable availability and accessibility of jobs and of opportunities that are appropriate to the person's skills and capabilities.

There are two particular problems with this approach in terms of the Bill we have before us. Initially there is the linking impairment with a very strict and unreasonable definition of continuing inability to work and the actual impairment tables themselves. The definition of a continuing inability to work in section 94 means that a person will not be eligible for the disability support pension if that person could theoretically be retrained for some unspecified job that exists anywhere in Australia. The secretary is specifically not allowed to have regard to the availability of work in the person's local labour market or the realistic availability of retraining for that person. The only exception to this is for people aged over 55 years where the Department of Social Security is permitted to look at the local labour market in determining whether a person has a continuing inability to work.

This approach will undoubtedly lead to hardship and inequity. For example, a totally blind person with a university qualification in, say, law, living in the inner suburbs of Melbourne or Sydney is under this Bill technically eligible for a pension. But what about a 50-year-old man with moderate alcohol brain damage who did not complete secondary education, is functionally illiterate in English and lives in a country town where unemployment is already running well over 30 per cent? Even if this man's functional impairment is assessed at more than 20 per cent on the impairment assessment table scale, the inability of the Department to take into account other factors could well mean that this man will not be eligible for a pension and will be forced to take up a Jobsearch allowance.

Here comes another problem. He will have to jump through all those hoops, climb over all those hurdles, and his disability may very well cause him to fail some of the draconian tests that are in that legislation-another person who has fallen through the social security net. It will mean a loss not only of income but also of his pensioner health benefits card and the additional pharmaceutical supplement. This is not an isolated example. It will not be just a few isolated cases of people who are affected. There will be many people with disabilities who will start falling through these new gaps in the social security system. No doubt it will save the Government money in its social security budget, but whether it ultimately costs the community more is another matter altogether. The costs to the lives of many disabled people and their families cannot be calculated.

The impairment tables have been the subject of enormous criticism from all the witnesses. All of them had some comments relating to the impairment tables and some, in particular those who were concerned about the psychiatric impairment tables and those relating to people with drug and alcohol problems, were very critical. Many organisations have been critical. Academics and doctors are claiming that these tables are fundamentally flawed in two respects. First, their validity is in question with the Department actually acknowledging that at least one table is totally untested. Secondly, there are serious concerns about the summing and the way in which we are looking at adding up from table to table.

Different tables in this Bill rely upon different scales to add up across the different tables. This will cause particular difficulties for people who are multi disabled or those with psychiatric, and alcohol and drug related disabilities. As a representative from one organisation said to me yesterday, `It is as if we are to add an apple to an orange and come out with a banana'. The Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) is aware of these criticisms. People have visited him as late as yesterday, going over the same ground, explaining the difficulties. I understand that, in fact, further amendments are being drawn up today and I wonder when we will see them. I hope that they are in this particular area.

One such critic of the tables is Dr Hugh Dickson, director of rehabilitation and geriatrics at the Liverpool Health Service, who wrote a letter in August which I will quote briefly. Senator Alston saw this letter yesterday when he discussed the incorporation of a graph. The letter states:

While I understand that there is a desire to establish that a significant impairment exists in an individual applying for the pension, and that this impairment results in a disability sufficient to prevent employment, there appears to be a confusion as to the nature of the tables and the applicability of mathematical processes both within and between tables. As these tables are a mixture of ordinal and interval scales that masquerade as ratio scales, procedures such as addition, subtraction and multiplication as used in the combined values chart are unsound and should be abandoned.

1. Impairment Tables

The problem with constructing Tables of Impairment is that a consistent measurement of function for all organ and structural systems in the body does not exist. There is no method of determining, for instance, the exact degree of impairment of liver function or dysfunction. Measurement of impairment of joint function is somewhat easier, as angles of movement, are readily measurable, but other aspects of function such as the speed of movement, or strength of movement which may be impaired by pain or inflammatory change are difficult to quantify.
Types of Measurement
There are four general levels of measurement: nominal, ordinal, interval and ratio.
Nominal measurement indicates that numbers are assigned to objects without having a number meaning, such as the numbers worn by members of a football team.

Ordinal measurement indicates that a rank order has been established and nothing more. The numbers do not indicate absolute quantities, nor do they indicate equal intervals between successive numbers.
Interval measurement indicates that rank ordering is present and that the equal intervals between successive numbers on the scale correspond to equal intervals in the property under measurement.
Ratio measurement indicates rank ordering, numerical equivalence between the side and the measured property and an absolute zero where none of the measured property is present.
Combining Values

It may be seen that the Tables are a mixture of ordinal, interval and ratio scales. The functional aspects as described in the scales are ordinal measures, despite the attempted use of a ratio scale, the percentage system. While mathematical procedures have been devised for handling ordinal scales, these scales are not designed to allow mathematical procedures such as AB(1-A). A simple substitution of the actual description (the measure) instead of its numerical equivalent demonstrates nicely that a number of different properties are being handled in the ordinal scale and not one property that is behaving in a uniform manner. There is no standard unit of impairment, just as there is no standard unit of disability.
Confusion of impairment and disability.
The tables confuse these two categories.
Impairment according to the WHO International Classification of Impairment, Disabilities and Handicaps is any loss or abnormality of psychological, physiological on anatomical structure or function.
Disability is any restriction or lack (resulting from an impairment) of ability to perform an activity in the manner or range considered normal for a human being.
Thus one can be impaired without being disabled.

Handicap is a disadvantage for a given individual, resulting from an impairment or a disability that limits or prevents the fulfilment of a role that is normal (depending on age, sex and social and cultural factors) for that individual.
The tables are a mixture of impairment criteria (Table 2 and Table 2.2) and disability criteria (Table 4).
Use of diagnoses

Impairment is not contingent on specific diagnoses or specific disorders. A number of conditions cause blindness, and a number of conditions cause cardiac failure or deafness or whatever. The tables should use the broad classification of impairment rather than the narrow definition of diagnosis as an exhaustive list of diagnoses causing impairment and disability is not feasible or particularly useful in this context.

In the latter two pages Dr Dickson explains in some detail the unsound basis of the tables. He is not alone in his concern, and I urge the Minister to consider delaying the Bill at least for another few weeks so that this matter can be further examined.

In the committee stage of the debate we will be raising the matter of monitoring. We need to monitor both the effects and the impacts of these tables as well as the impact of the Bill. At the very least, I urge the Government to take up the suggestion of the Australian Council of Alcohol and Other Drug Associations to establish and resource an independent monitoring panel to keep track of what is happening and what these tables are doing.

Another area of concern to the Democrats is the severe income cuts for those under the age of 21. This is a really disgraceful decision and one that all Government senators should be utterly ashamed of. This is not a hole in the social security net but rather a poverty trap. The last plank in this policy, the last group to be affected, is the young disabled. Alongside this, in recognition of the extra expenses to be borne by young people with disabilities, the Government will provide a youth disability supplement to people under 21. This supplement will be aligned with the child disability allowance.

This all is rather esoteric until we actually look at the figures. A single person under 18 living at home now receives an invalid pension of $301.60 a fortnight. Under the new arrangements, the disability support pension is only $124.10 per fortnight, plus the youth disability supplement of $59.90. This leaves such persons $117.60 per fortnight worse off-a massive drop in income.

The situation is the same in all other categories. Single people under 18 living away from home will be worse off by $18.45 per week; single people under 21 living at home will be worse off by $46.30 per week; single people under 21 who are independent-living away from home-will be worse off by $7.60 per week. The figures for young people still living at home are of great concern. I have received many letters from parents of young disabled people who are worried about the effects these cuts will have on their continuing ability to care for these young people at home. I shall read a letter from some parents in southern Adelaide who are part of a group called Parents of Disabled, Southern Area. The letter says:

Our young people are already isolated in their schooling and local community, and we feel that by reducing their income they will be further disadvantaged. We also wonder where they will be employed when so many able-bodied people are without paid employment. Our children are in receipt of pensions because of their disabilities which are permanent.

The members of this group go on to point out a variety of occasions when extra costs are incurred. These parents point out that any loss in their child's income could have disastrous consequences. They argue that the margins are already tight for many of these families. They ask what will happen if some families are forced to place their young people into regular full time care. How will Senator Richardson and the Government justify this additional cost to the community?

There is also a problem with community organisations that are providing accommodation. Many of those organisations take a percentage of the pension. It is not cheaper to look after a person of 19 or 20 compared to a person of 23 to 25. It has been pointed out to the Government many times that the cost of living is the same for all people, whether they are between the ages of 16 and 20, 21 and 30, or indeed beyond. I note that Mr Braithwaite, the shadow Minister for community services, recognised this when he spoke in the House of Representatives on 4 June. He stated then:
We are also concerned that payment for 16-to 20-year-olds will fall below single invalid pension rates.

He went on to point out that this decision fails to recognise the extra cost of a disability and overlooks the real needs of a person with disabilities, particularly in this young age group, which are education, training, transport, and outreach into an adult community. I hope that Opposition senators and perhaps Government senators will support amendments in the committee stage that will remove this injustice and leave young people with a reasonable income.

There has been some progress in the area of the mobility allowance. We welcome the increase in the allowance and the slight extension of the eligibility criteria. This does not go anywhere near far enough and, again, it is a specific recommendation of the report I quoted earlier that a disability allowance should be introduced for all people of working age. The Cass report recommends that such an allowance be provided to people engaged in education, training, job search, employment, community or voluntary activities and those engaged in what the report called caring work, especially household work, child-care, et cetera. The Cass report saw this as being a recognition of the extra cost borne by people with disabilities as they participate in the major areas of activity usually expected of adults.

In conclusion, I emphasise that this Bill continues the recent tradition of poorly conceived legislation that has been a hallmark of Senator Richardson's time in the social security portfolio. Why must legislation be pushed so quickly through the House of Representatives and this place, without any opportunity for many organisations and, indeed, for honourable senators to look at it? I urge Senator Richardson to have another look at this Bill. We will have time to do that; it will probably be Monday before we even get to the committee stage. There is still time to have another look at this piece of legislation.

We have at least 110 amendments to this Bill, and that number may be growing. While we have removed some of the flaws, some of the inconsistencies, and closed some of the gaps, there is still a long way to go. This Minister's failure to consult with the people affected by the Bill is indicative of the arrogance of this Government and of its inability to realise that it is not dealing just with facts and figures on a legislature sheet; it is dealing with the lives and well-being of thousands of people. It is insulting to these people and deliberately misleading to paint a rosy picture of an active employment scheme for people with disabilities in one year's Budget and to then to introduce in a subsequent year-claiming that everyone supports it-a very different document, one that has been significantly altered and includes a number of harsh new measures, which none of the groups directly affected had seen before the Bill turned up on the floor of the Parliament. I am not sure what style of government this approach represents, but I am certain it is not democracy.

This Bill will cause the Government a lot of trouble. I conclude by quoting from the South Australian Consumer Advocacy Program, which sent me a fax yesterday and, I understand, many other senators. It states:
Save yourselves work and embarrassment! Delay this Bill until the Minister gets it right!
