TALK.START.PARA: —Few people will dispute that the administration of law tends to lag significantly behind the commercial developments that it controls. Today I would like to give the Senate an extreme example of this and in so doing exhort the Government to support an urgent change to the tax administration of swap financing. Second only to the making of loans themselves, the provision of the corporate banking interest rate risk management device known as swap financing represents the largest part of the service provided by the banks to corporate customers in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Swap financing involves billions of dollars a year. The problem is that swap financing is a highly sophisticated and up-to-date development in international banking but, unfortunately, the Australian Taxation Office is insisting on a medieval tax treatment which is a bit like trying to run a very fast train on wooden rails. I will give an explanation of swap financing because it appears to be a somewhat complicated arrangement.

Put simply, swap financing is an interest rate risk management tool. For example, a company might borrow money that is subject to an interest charge that fluctuates or floats according to market rates. A company therefore may not be comfortable with that type of risk. If so, it can then go to a major bank and arrange to exchange or swap its interest obligation at a floating rate for a swap obligation at a fixed rate. Mechanically, this is achieved simply by the company periodically paying the bank an amount calculated at a fixed rate over the term of the underlying loan and receiving in return payments at a floating rate which the company then uses to fund the interest payments on that underlying loan.

The proposition I am putting to the Senate today is: what is the appropriate method of accounting for this interest rate swap? There are basically three approaches. Firstly, there is the cash accounting approach, unfortunately adopted by the Australian Taxation Office, which is referred to as the medieval approach. Secondly, there is the daily accruals approach which was widely adopted in the 1960s. Then there is the third and preferred approach used internationally today, which is referred to as the mark to market approach. That is the approach adopted by sophisticated countries in the 1990s. It is also used as a method of overcoming tax avoidance. This third alternative is economically the most correct method. In fact, it has already been adopted in the United Kingdom and has recently been proposed by the US Internal Revenue Service as the standard tax accounting method in the United States.

This financial accounting and tax accounting method seeks to arrive at a true net profit or loss for the period for a particular swap transaction entered into by a bank or a corporate by taking into account both the past realised profit or loss and the future unrealised profit or loss in relation to the balance of the term of the swap transaction. The unrealised portion is arrived at by calculating the present value of the remaining cash flows under the swap transaction according to the current market rates rather than the rates of interest prevailing when the swap transaction was originally entered into.

This is accepted in the US and the UK, and by many banks in Australia, as being the only true and complete application of the income or loss from the total transaction. This is because it is the only method which values future cash flows as well as accounting for past cash flows. I therefore urge the Australian Taxation Office and the Australian Government to adopt the mark to market approach as being the correct approach.

The second approach was used extensively during the 1960s-this demonstrates how old and archaic the Australian taxation ruling is-and is a compromise approach. It provides a form of net profit accounting but at the same time is a method which fits into traditional financial accounting concepts of historical cost and which also has the benefit of substantial support in traditional Australian tax accounting legal precedents. The accruals method involves the daily accrual of the amounts payable and the amounts receivable under the swap by each party to the swap over the period of time to which the swap payable or receivable relates. This approach is consistent with the traditional general financial accounting principles in Australia, reflecting as it does the matching concept which is fundamental to financial accounting.

In terms of traditional tax law, this type of approach is strongly supported by the earnings basis in the derivation of income as was shown in the Arthur Murray case in 1965, 114 Commonwealth Law Reports 314 and the consumed cost or expense basis of deduction as shown in the Australian Guarantee Corporation case 84 ATC 4642. These cases are themselves based on the financial accounting concept recognised universally as matching. The net effect, over a particular period, of the accruals method is to strike a net realised profit or loss in respect of the swap transaction for the period. However, unlike the correct mark to market approach, no account is taken of the value at balance date of the rest of the transaction. It is therefore only a partial view of the whole of the transaction.

Finally, it is quite apparent that because swap transactions hedge interest obligations-or receivables in the case of interest bearing assets-swap cash flows in an economic sense substitute for interest cash flows or at least are analogous to interest cash flows. Accordingly, just as interest as such is at present accounted for on a daily accrual basis for tax purposes, so logically should swap payments be accounted for in the same way or, preferably, on a mark to market basis. Indeed, a mismatch here would significantly reduce the value of the swap as a hedging instrument and thus threaten the continued viability of this valuable financial method management service for the Australian corporate sector.

However, notwithstanding the force of these arguments for the daily accruals basis, the Commissioner of Taxation is proposing to insist that financial institutions and corporates adopt the due and payable/due and receivable or cash basis. Disastrous consequences will flow from the use of this archaic or medieval approach of a technique that went out in the old days when accounting was first emerging.

The cash basis has a number of disastrous consequences not only for the Australian revenue-consequences which the Taxation Office should have been able to foresee before it made this disastrous ruling-but also for Australian industry. The cash basis approach, which simply makes swap payments deductible at the time of the payment and the swap receipts assessable at the time of receipt, is an open invitation to Australian taxpayers, whether dealing with swap counterparties in Australia or overseas-and I think that is important-to manipulate to the disadvantage of the revenue the timing, that is the important word, of swap payments and receipts so as to defer taxable income.

I will give an example of this tax manipulation under the cash transaction method. A substantial up-front payment made to a swap counterparty outside Australia representing the present value of future periodic swap payments could be made shortly before the end of a taxpayer's financial year. This may or may not occur for good commercial reasons. Under the cash method the payment would attract a tax deduction, while the future receipt under the swap transaction received in the following year would be assessable to tax only in that following financial year. The deferral of tax created by the mismatch of payments and receipts could be perpetuated by the repetition of such transactions each following year.

On the other hand, the mark to market method will calculate a net profit or loss irrespective of the timing of the cash flows and thus avoid such artificial arbitrage problems. Likewise, the accrual method, by spreading receipts and payments over the swap payment period to which they relate, will also avoid such problems.

Secondly, the Taxation Office approach will put the Australian financing industry at a competitive disadvantage to its non-resident counterparts with whom it must deal on a daily basis. In turn, this will detrimentally affect the Australian corporate sector involved in swap financing arrangements.

Under the mark to market method-or the accruals approach-swap transactions can effectively be priced without taking account of the timing of tax payments. This is because the amount of taxable income generated in a particular year of income will not be affected by when cash swap payments are actually made or received. However, under the cash method proposed and demanded by the Australian Taxation Office, where swap receipts exceed swap payments in a year of income, tax will be paid earlier than would otherwise be the case. Accordingly, a swap transaction that has the effect of generating an earlier payment of tax by an Australian bank counterparty will need to have built into the effective rates of interest at which the swap payments are calculated an amount to compensate the Australian counterparty for carrying the cost of having to pay the tax sooner, rather than evenly over the carrying cost of the effective life of the transaction.

Given the fact that swap business is highly competitive on an international basis, the Australian bank counterparties will quickly be priced out of such a market. This competitive disadvantage has a flow-on effect to Australian companies. As the swap hedging service to Australian corporates provided by the Australian banks is substantially dependent on the banks being able to offset their positions in the international market, the swap hedging facility will simply disappear from the Australian financial scene to the massive detriment of Australian industry as well as to the banking sector itself.

Thirdly, in order for the Australian financial sector to participate effectively in the global financial system, it is important that there be consistency of both the accounting and tax treatment of financing transactions undertaken throughout the world, because we are not an island isolated unto ourselves. For Australia now to adopt a cash basis of tax accounting would be a retrograde step and would remove Australia further away from, rather than closer to, the tax and accounting approaches adopted by the other financial centres around the world.

Therefore, Mr Deputy President, I make a recommendation through you to this Senate and to the Government. My recommendation-and this is widely supported by the accounting community-is that the Australian Taxation Office should adopt the mark to market method of tax accounting for all swap transactions. I urge the Senate to support this recommendation and to do so immediately as the Taxation Office is about to release a final ruling on this matter.

Secondly, if the Tax Office is intransigent I believe legislation should be introduced to amend the tax law to specifically provide for the tax accounting approach that I have recommended. Let us drag the tax treatment of these transactions into the 1990s, and in the process let us get the banking industry and the Australian corporate sector off these wooden rails.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to correct some of the statements made by Senator Olsen in this place in the last sitting week. In doing this I also express my concern that Senator Olsen raised some very controversial matters in the last Thursday lunchtime matters of public interest debate. In fact, he attacked me in this place during that debate on 22 August. I was not in the building. It was lunchtime. I did not have the opportunity to be in the chamber to rebut what he was claiming about me and to defend myself.

SPEECH.PARA: My understanding is that, by agreement, the Thursday lunchtime debate in this particular place-not this week, but normally-is for matters of public interest. I understand that the agreement is that non-controversial matters are raised at that particular time. I was appalled to read some time afterwards in the Hansard of 22 August that Senator Olsen, on a number of occasions, attacked me for a report in my name in the Adelaide afternoon newspaper, the Adelaide News, on 19 August. I would like to refer to that particular article because in it I actually publicised the very important, large and extensive reductions in sales tax on business and agricultural inputs provided in the recent Budget.

Senator Olsen, perhaps, has not been in this place long enough to understand that one does not raise controversial matters in those Thursday lunchtime debates. Certainly, one does not go out and attack other senators in them. The agreement is that people can go and have lunch. It is not an occasion for major debate, the idea being that matters of public interest only are raised at that time.

Senator Olsen also, apparently, does not understand the Budget process in Australia, even though at one stage he was the Leader of the Opposition in South Australia-a very senior post in the South Australian Parliament. From the tone of his remarks on 22 August he apparently does not believe that the sales tax reductions should be given any press attention at Budget time. They are major reductions in sales tax, they are of enormous value to Australian business and they are substantial measures which are integral parts of the current Budget. I would simply point out to Senator Olsen that the sales tax reductions do appear on at least two occasions in Budget Paper No. 1. My press report was about the Budget and it was referring to those sales tax cuts in the context of the Federal Budget.

They are important. I know there is concern on the other side of the chamber that by exempting more and more inputs into business production from sales tax, by exempting more raw materials and by exempting more productive equipment-capital equipment-from sales tax we, on this side, are further undermining the case for the broad-based consumption tax; we are further undermining the Liberals' case for a goods and services tax in this country by now reforming, renewing and reviewing the wholesale sales tax to remove a number of business inputs from that tax.

I understand the sensitivity on the other side about what we are doing to reform the sales tax. In this Budget, at a cost to revenue this financial year of $200m, we are removing a number of inputs into production from wholesale sales tax. This will have enormous benefit for Australian producers of traded goods, that is, Australian production which is exported or which competes directly with imports into this country. That $200m worth of sales tax reductions, that is, the cost to revenue of $200m, will have a big impact on lowering the cost of Australian business production. I point out that, while $200m will be lost to revenue this financial year, the loss to revenue next financial year will be a massive $375m, illustrating the scale of these sales tax reductions.

Senator Olsen claimed, in that supposedly non-controversial matters of public interest debate on 22 August, that I had said there would be $400m in sales tax cuts this financial year. The Budget Papers point out that this year there are to be sales tax cuts of $200m. Unfortunately, Senator Olsen did not understand what I was saying. I understand that Senator Olsen, before he became a member of parliament in South Australia, was also a small businessman, and I am surprised that he does not understand how sales tax impacts on business costs.

What I said, and this is how I was reported in the Adelaide News, was based on an understanding of how a costing works in business. That is what I said in my press release. We have to look at how a particular tax impacts on costs of production. While the cost to revenue of the sales tax reductions this financial year will be $200m, the value to business in terms of lower production costs is much larger than the $200m. The reason for that is that taxes on inputs, taxes on raw materials, taxes on capital equipment, are subject to the profit margins, the mark-ups on costs, that businesses apply to determine their surpluses.

As goods pass through the production chain, as goods at the early stages of the production chain are exempted from tax, there is a cascading effect on costs. If costs are lowered at an early stage of production, when a profit margin or a mark-up is applied to that lower cost base there is an even larger reduction on business costs. In fact, the $200m in revenue forgone by the Budget this financial year as a result of those sales tax reductions becomes much larger than $200m. That is the reason the Adelaide News quoted a figure of $400m this financial year as the value to business-not the cost to revenue but the value to business-of the sales tax reductions.

My press release makes it very clear, and I have a copy of it with me here. It says, `The total value to business will be ` `around double'' the cost to revenue'. The cost to revenue is $200m. My understanding is that around double $200m is $400m. Unfortunately Senator Olsen simply does not understand how business costing works. He jumped at a figure he saw in the Budget for the financial year 1993-94. In other words, there is a figure showing the cost to revenue of these sales tax cuts as being $405m in 1993-94, two financial years out from now. He thought I was talking about those figures. That is what he was attacking me for in the Senate on 22 August. Clearly, he just does not understand that the $200m cost to revenue this financial year will have an around double impact in reducing business costs, so a figure of up to $400m would be involved. As a result of the cascading effect as one reduces a cost at an early stage of production, through the profit margins this becomes magnified and one gets a bigger reduction in costs at subsequent stages in the chain of production.

We estimate that in the next financial year the cost to revenue of removing sales tax from all these inputs in production will be $375m. The cascading effect on costs-and I know Senator Watson would understand this; he understands business-will be not $375m but around $700m. We will see up to $700m in lower business costs as a result of these measures. I am surprised-Senator Olsen has been in small business-that he does not understand how a cost base cascades as a result of profit mark-ups. My comments as stated in the Adelaide News on 19 August are clearly right, despite the mistaken claims to the contrary made by Senator Olsen.

The reality is that these sales tax exemptions in the Budget will be a major boost for Australian business. They will lower the cost structure for those Australian businesses producing traded goods-that is, goods for export. Products will be more competitive compared with products sold in overseas markets. At the same time, these sales tax reductions will reduce the cost structure for goods produced and sold in Australia in competition with imported products. They will be more competitive because the cost reductions will not be available to the imported goods.

By reviewing the wholesale sales tax system now-what can actually be done to boost business profitability, to lower business cost levels by reforming the tax we now have-we will be able to see its impact without going down the road of a value added tax or a broad based consumption tax. We do not need to have one of those taxes to help lower business costs. We can do it by reviewing sales tax collections on business inputs in the present system. That is what we have done in this Budget at a cost to revenue this financial year of $200m.

The other reason we do not need to have a new tax is that the present wholesale sales tax is a very efficient and simple tax to collect. It is collected at the wholesale level. There are relatively few wholesalers-probably about 75,000-in Australia. Most people could not even name a wholesaler, there are so few of them. On the other hand, there are probably three-quarters of a million retail businesses in Australia. All of those retail businesses would be in the value added tax net that Dr Hewson wants to put them in by introducing a value added tax.

It is very illuminating to look at the latest annual report of the Australian Taxation Office. The present wholesale sales tax costs about 50c for every $100 of revenue collected; so about one-half of one per cent of all revenue collected by the Taxation Office goes in administration costs. I have seen studies of the value added tax system in the United Kingdom which suggest that $2 out of every $100 collected from that tax goes in administrative costs. One can see that the present wholesale sales tax in Australia is a very efficient tax to collect. I cannot understand why people on the other side are saying that it should be reformed because it is a complex tax when, clearly, its collection costs are far lower per dollar of revenue collected than the collection costs of the value added tax.

I conclude by pointing out that with these particular taxes it is not just a matter of the cost to government in collecting these taxes; there is also a huge cost involved to businesses themselves-the small business proprietors, the large businesses-with a value added tax along the lines being proposed by the Liberals. While the Liberals claim that a number of businesses have come out in support of their value added tax, one of Australia's largest retailers, one of Australia's largest proprietors of department stores-the David Jones organisation-is already on the public record as saying that, if the Liberals were ever to be in government and were ever to bring in a consumption tax, a value added tax, David Jones would demand that all of its cash registers, all of its computing systems and computer programming software be converted at government expense to meet the new requirements for a value added tax. So let us have none of this nonsense about the superiority of so-called broad-based consumption taxes over the wholesale sales tax. We can reduce the impact of the wholesale sales tax on business by continuing to reform and review the tax base.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, upon notice, on 19 June 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: What is the reason for the move of the noise complaints unit from the Civil Aviation Authority to the Federal Airports Corporation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: It has been decided to move the aircraft noise complaint function from the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) to the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) because:

(1) aircraft noise complaints usually arise as the result of aircraft movements into and out of an airport; therefore it is most appropriate that the authority responsible for generating those aircraft movements - the operator of that airport - be granted responsibility for dealing with the local community on problems created by the airport

(2) the FAC has a legislated responsibility to be a `good neighbour' and is constantly dealing with the local community on a range of issues; therefore dealing with aircraft noise complaints will essentially be an extension of the FAC's current community consultation activities
(3) being the airport operator the FAC has closer links with the local communities than the CAA and is better placed to address local issues such as the impact of aircraft noise.
The Civil Aviation Authority will continue to be responsible for the technical aspects of noise and flight path monitoring.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 11 July 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to an article entitled `Tax and Counterattacks' which appeared in the Weekend Australian of 6 July 1991, page 31:
(1) Who was the author of the article accredited to the Treasurer (Mr Kerin).
(2) What is the basis for the claim in the article that a 15 per cent consumption tax would result in a 7 per cent boost in prices.
(3) What assumptions are used to make this claim and what part of the Treasury, the Australian Public Service or other organisation was responsible for this estimate.

(4) With respect to the claim that compensation for a consumption tax with a price effect of 7 per cent would leave a `funding gap' of $3 billion, what precisely is this funding gap composed of, what are all the assumptions necessary to reach the conclusion of a $3 billion `funding gap' and whose estimate is this.

(5) What was the `funding gap' associated with the preferred option consumption tax promoted by the then Treasurer (Mr Keating) in 1985, and for what reasons does the current Treasurer believe the `funding gap' would be $3 billion now and not the level it was thought in 1985, given that the coverage of the wholesale sales tax has been significantly widened since 1985 such that if its abolition and replacement with a broad goods and services tax were to occur now, the need for compensation for such a proposal would be presumably less than in 1985.

(6) What are all the assumptions required to verify the claim that the net effect on national saving would be negative because private savings would not be expected to match the claimed $3 billion `funding gap'.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The article to which Senator Alston refers was divided into three parts, each reflecting the opinion of a different person - the Treasurer, John Kerin, the shadow Treasurer, Peter Reith and the journalist, Nick Richardson. The Treasurer was the author of that part of the article accredited to him.

(2) The estimate of an inflationary effect of 7 per cent resulting from a 15 per cent consumption tax is that provided to this Parliament on 22 August 1990 by the then Treasurer, Mr Keating. See answer to (3) below for details of how the estimate was derived.
(3) The calculations were prepared by the Taxation Policy Division of the Treasury. The assumptions underlying the calculations in (2) above were:
(i) estimates were for the 1990-91 financial year;
(ii) goods and services were weighted by the March 1990 quarter CPI weights;
(iii) a standard ad valorem retail mark-up of 20 per cent was assumed;
(iv) any decrease or increase in taxation was assumed to be reflected fully in retail prices;

(v) the consumption tax base used was private final consumption expenditure minus expenditure on health, education, financial services and dwelling rent. However, it was assumed that inputs into these services would be taxed. Further, it was assumed that no additional revenue would be collected from products currently subject to excise (petroleum products, tobacco and alcohol) following the introduction of a consumption tax, effectively excluding them from the base.
(vi) the consumption tax would replace the wholesale sales tax (WST).

(4) The cost of compensating for the introduction of a consumption tax was also a Treasury Taxation Policy Division estimate. The `funding gap' of $3 billion is composed of revenue from a 15 per cent consumption tax, minus revenue forgone by abolishing the wholesale sales tax, minus compensation to social security recipients and taxpayers for the direct CPI effects of the new tax. The assumptions used in arriving at the `funding gap' include those detailed in (3) above. The cost of compensating social security recipients was estimated by updating the aggregates presented in the June 1985 Draft White Paper "Reform of the Australian Tax System", and is therefore consistent with the methodology used there. The cost of compensating income tax payers was estimated using the Draft White Paper methodology.

(5) The preferred consumption tax option at a rate of 12.5 per cent outlined in the 1985 Draft White Paper would have yielded a net revenue gain of $6.8 billion in 1984-85 after some compensation (other than through the income tax system) and allowance for abolition of the WST. In 1990-91, by comparison, a fully compensated consumption tax applied at that rate (based on the assumptions outlined above, including compensatory income tax cuts) would have resulted in a `funding gap' of $2.5 billion.

There are three main reasons why the 1985 and 1990 `funding gap' estimates differ. First, the revenue base of the consumption tax in 1985 included a class of goods called `restricted' goods, such as fuel, cars and building materials, which were taxed whether purchased by businesses or consumers. These were included in the assumed 1985 tax base to overcome potential avoidance problems and the administrative difficulty that would arise from attempting to separate (tax- exempt) business use from (taxable) private use. However, most advocates of a consumption tax wish to relieve the indirect tax impost on business inputs and therefore the 1990 calculations do not include `restricted' goods in the assumed tax base. In short, the assumed 1990 consumption tax base is narrower, and falls relatively more heavily on final demand, than the one used in the Draft White Paper.

Secondly, the wholesale sales tax base has been broadened substantially since 1985. While this tends to reduce the price compensation necessitated by a switch to a consumption tax, it also reduces the net revenue gain from the switch. The latter effect was estimated to be larger than the former effect.

Thirdly, the net revenue raised from the black economy by a consumption tax is not as large as it would have been in 1985. In 1985 the consumption tax would have applied to expenditure from income that was not taxed; that expenditure would therefore not have attracted compensation through income tax cuts. However, because the Government expanded the income tax base to combat tax avoidance and evasion, the cost of compensating income tax payers for CPI increases has increased substantially.
The Treasury is currently upgrading its capacity to model indirect tax changes. It can be expected that that work will shed more light on these issues.

(6) The former Treasurer, in his National Press Club Address of 9 May 1990 detailed the reasons that a consumption tax, particularly one with a funding gap of $3 billion, would not result in a net increase in national savings. I commend the Honourable Senator to read that address.
